facts.text: Appellant Company carries on activity as engineers and contractors in different parts of West Bengal with a store yard at Sukchar employing 30 workmen, 11 permanent and remaining temporary.
Practice of appellant Company: fourteen days holidays in each year including 1st of January; if holiday fell on Sunday, following day made holiday.
11 permanent workmen did not attend work on 2nd January 1961 treating it as holiday; Company case: expressly told due to pressure of work 2nd January working day, holiday in lieu later.
Absent workmen given charge-sheet, placed under suspension before enquiry, dismissed after enquiry.
Union instance led to reference to Labour Officer for conciliation which failed as Company did not appear.
Government of West Bengal referred to Labour Tribunal on April 21, 1961: 'Whether the dismissal of the following 11 workmen is justified, what relief if any they are entitled to'.

Tribunal award dated May 4, 1962: no lock-out or lay-off; workmen went on strike which was not illegal; dismissal victimization, unjustified in severity for one day strike; set aside dismissal, reinstatement with back wages except for January 2, 1961.

Enquiry Officer recommended dismissal of only 8 workmen; 3 excused: Quigly (Christian, informed Works Manager, excused with warning and deprivation of wages for 2nd Jan); J.C. Bose (joined 31 Dec, not aware, warned, absence against leave); A.K. Sarkar (on leave till 31 Dec, informed by Quigly it was holiday, warned, absence as leave).
Three excused workmen ordered to join duty but did not as Union opined original dispute pending for conciliation.

legal_issues.text: Whether the reference is bad because it refers to 11 workmen as dismissed when only 8 were so treated.
Whether the Tribunal was justified in interfering with the punishment of dismissal after concluding workmen went on strike even though strike not illegal.

petitioner_arguments.text: Reference bad as only 8 workmen dismissed, not 11.
Tribunal cannot interfere with finding or quantum of punishment; management's prerogative to decide punishment for misconduct under Standing Orders; no victimization shown.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Principles from cases like Bengal Bhatdee Coal Co., Buckingham Carnatic Co., etc.

petitioner_arguments.text: Workmen found guilty at enquiry and by Tribunal; punishment matter for employer.

respondent_arguments.text: Conduct of workmen regarded as collective strike, result of conspiracy; only permanent workers targeted, ulterior motive to break Union by using temporary hands.

court_reasoning.text: Reference valid as all 11 charged together, common defence on holiday practice; three could not join due to Union; Government entitled to treat as single dispute.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Technically correct but no interference on this ground alone.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal powers limited: interfere only for lack of bona fides, victimization, unfair practice, basic error, natural justice violation, or shockingly disproportionate punishment no reasonable employer would impose.

Punishment shockingly disproportionate: established practice of next day holiday; nothing special on 2nd Jan; absence could be leave without pay, warning, fine; no reasonable employer would dismiss entire permanent staff.

holdings.text: No interference with award on ground of reference to 11 workmen.
Tribunal justified in interfering as punishment shockingly disproportionate, no reasonable employer would impose.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bengal Bhatdee Coal Co. Ltd. v. Ram Probesh Singh Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Principles for Tribunal interference in punishment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Buckingham Carnatic Co. Ltd. v. Workers
Titaghur Paper Mills Co. Ltd. v. Ram Naresh Kumar
Doom Dooma Tea Co. Ltd. v. Assam Chah Karamchari Sangh
Punjab National Bank Ltd. v. Workmen
Chartered Bank Bombay v. Chartered Bank Employees Union
precedents_cited.relevance: Limits on Tribunal substituting its view.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference to Tribunal, award powers implied.

statutes_cited.name: Standing Orders
statutes_cited.relevance: Punishment for misconduct under Standing Orders matter for management.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed; Tribunal's award upheld setting aside dismissal of 11 workmen and ordering reinstatement with back wages except for January 2, 1961, as punishment was shockingly disproportionate.

key_quotes.text: "the punishment imposed was one which no reasonable employer would have imposed in like circumstances unless it served some other purpose."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on disproportionate punishment justifying interference.

key_quotes.text: "Tribunal should not interfere with the kind or severity of punishment except in very extraordinary circumstances."
key_quotes.speaker: court
